facts.text: Civil Appeal 271 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal 271 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated May 18, 1959 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in L.P.A. No. 24-D of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 18, 1959 of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in L. P. A. No. 24-D of 1956.

facts.text: Certificate granted by Punjab High Court for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the Punjab High Court.

facts.text: Appellant selected for post of Programme Assistant on May 3, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was selected for the post of Programme Assistant on May 3, 1949

facts.text: Appellant appointed on probation for one year.

anchor.surface_text: and was appointed on probation for one year, and the letter of appointment said

facts.text: Letter of appointment stated services might be terminated without notice and without cause during probation.

anchor.surface_text: that during the said period his services might be determinated without any numberice and without any cause being assigned.

facts.text: Appellant accepted offer and joined service on June 4, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: He was asked to accept the offer on this companydition. The appellant accepted the offer and joined service on June 4, 1949.

facts.text: Probation period expired on June 3, 1950 but extended from time to time.

anchor.surface_text: His period of probation expired on June 3, 1950, but it was extended from time to time.

facts.text: On July 4, 1952, appellant informed probation period would not be extended and called to show cause why services should not be terminated.

anchor.surface_text: On July 4, 1952, the appellant was informed that his probation period companyld number be extended and was called upon to show cause why his services should

facts.text: Appellant showed cause against termination.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant showed cause.

facts.text: Appellant informed explanation not satisfactory and services terminated after August 31, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: He was finally in- formed that the explanation given by him was number satisfactory and that his services were to be terminated after August 31, 1952.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Punjab High Court

facts.text: Punjab High Court held appellant not entitled to Art. 311(2) protection.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the appellant was number entitled to the protection of Art. 311  2  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Punjab High Court held rr. 49 and 55-B did not apply, governed by contract.

anchor.surface_text: It further held that rr. 49 and 55-B of the Rules did number apply to the appellant and he was governed by the companytract of his service which provided that his services might be terminated without any

facts.text: High Court dismissed petition but granted certificate for appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was companysequently dismissed, but the High Court granted a certificate to the appellant that the case was a fit one for appeal to this Court

facts.text: Appellant never confirmed in appointment. Not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It, is number in dispute that the appellant was never companyfirmed in his appointment.

facts.text: Probation period extended from time to time. Not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It is also number in dispute that though the letter of appointment said that the appellant will be on probation for a period of one year, his probation period was extended from time to time.

facts.text: On December 6, 1951, appellant informed work below standard, defects pointed out, opportunity to improve.

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1951 soon after the appellants probation was extended up to June 3, 1952, he was informed that during the period he had been employed his work had been found to be much below the standard required for the post.

facts.text: July 4, 1952 notice to show cause why services should not be terminated, defects listed.

anchor.surface_text: On July 4, 1952, the appellant was given a numberice by which he was afforded an opportunity to show cause why his services should number be terminated and was informed that any representation made by him in this regard would be duly companysidered.

facts.text: Appellant gave explanation to July 4, 1952 notice, considered not satisfactory on July 31, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant gave his explanation in reply to this numberice which was duly companysidered and on July 31, 1962, he was informed that his explanation had number been companysidered satisfactory

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered February 18, 1963 by WANCHOO J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. February 18. The judgment of the companyrt was delivered by WANCHOO J.

facts.text: r.49 amended October 10, 1947 with Explanation 2.

anchor.surface_text: It is number well settled that the protection of Art. 311 of the Constitution applies to temporary government servants also where dismissal, removal or reduction in rank is sought to be inflicted by way of punishment. issues.text: whether the appellant is entitled to the protection of Art. 311(2)

anchor.surface_text: Two questions thus arise in this connection the first is whether in view of r. 3  a  the appellant will number be entitled to the protection of r. 55-B, and the second is whether he was afforded the protection of r. 55-B before action was taken to terminate his service if that rule applies.

Besides it was urged on his behalf that he was governed by rr. 49 and 55-B of the Civil Services  Classification, Control and appeal  Rules  hereinafter referred to as the Rules  and therefore lie was entitled to the protection of those rules.

issues.text: whether Explanation 2 to r. 49 of the Rules as amended on October 10, 1947 applied making termination amount to removal or dismissal under Art. 311(2)

anchor.surface_text: In this connection reliance is placed on Explanation 2 to r. 49 of the Rules, as amended of October 10, 1947. That Explanation read as follows - The discharge of a probationer whether during or at the end of the period of probation, for some specific fault or on account of his unsuitability for the service, amounts to removal or dismissal within the meaning of this rule.

arguments.claim: Art.311 protection applies to temporary servants only if punitive; not otherwise; services terminable per contract or 1 month notice (citing Parshotam Lal Dhingra)

anchor.surface_text: It is number well settled that the protection of Art. 311 of the Constitution applies to temporary government servants also where dismissal, removal or reduction in rank is sought to be inflicted by way of punishment. But it is equally well settled that where the services of a temporary government servant are terminated number by way of punishment, Art. 311 will number apply... see, Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India  1 .

arguments.claim: Probationer discharge not dismissal/removal under Art.311(2) if per rules and not punitive; no right to post (citing State of Orissa v. Ram Narain Das)

anchor.surface_text: Further it is equally well settled that a government servant who is on probation can be discharged and such discharge would number amount to dismissal or removal within the meaning of Art. 311  2  and would number attract the protection of that Article where the services of a probationer are terminated in accordance with the rules and number by way of punishment... see The State of Orissa v. Rant Narain Das  1 .

arguments.claim: Termination here not punitive, so no Art.311(2)

anchor.surface_text: The first question that falls for determination is whether the appellant is entitled to the protection of Art. 311  2  ... There is also numberdoubt that the termination of his service was number by way of punishment and cannot therefore amount to dismissal or removal within the meaning of Art. 311.

arguments.claim: New Explanation to r.49 (post-1949) governs: termination per probation terms not removal/dismissal under r.49/55 or Art.311(2)

anchor.surface_text: But we find that r. 49 was further amended in November 1949 and by that amendment Explanation 2 was deleted... This new Explanation which was in force at the relevant time, is in these terms The termination of employment-  a  of a person appointed on probation during or at the end of the period of probation, in accordance with the terms of the appointment... does number amount to removal or dismissal within the meaning of this rule or of rule 55.

arguments.claim: r.55-B applies to appellant; not excluded by r.3(a) as contract term not special provision under law

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3  a  thus excludes the application of the Rules only in case of persons for whose appointment and companyditions of employment special provision is made by or under any law... It cannot be said therefore that the term already mentioned... is a special provision by virtue of any law... The High Court was therefore in our opinion number right in holding that r. 55-B will number apply to the appellant because of this term in the letter of appointment issued to him.

arguments.claim: r.55-B complied with: grounds apprised via Dec 6 1951 letter (defects, opportunity to improve) and July 4 1952 notice (defects listed, show cause); explanation considered July 31 1952

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1951... he was informed that during the period he had been employed his work had been found to be much below the standard... The main defects... pointed out... given opportunity... On July 4, 1952, the appellant was given a numberice... afforded opportunity to show cause... defects pointed out... explanation... duly companysidered... informed... number satisfactory.

arguments.claim: r.55-B requires only grounds communication and show cause opportunity, not full r.55 procedure (which is for punitive cases under Art.311(2))

anchor.surface_text: Rule 55 however deals with cases of removal, dismissal or reduction in rank, which are specifically companyered by Art. 311  2  of the Constitution and the procedure prescribed therein is meant for these three major punishments. That procedure is number meant to be applicable under r. 55-B which deals with the discharge of a probationer which is number a punishment at all.

holdings.text: The appellant was not entitled to the protection of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The High Court therefore was right in holding that the appellant was not entitled to the protection of Art 311 2 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant was probationer; termination not by way of punishment but simple discharge subject to rules; does not amount to dismissal or removal; follows Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India and State of Orissa v. Ram Narain Das

holdings.text: Contention that Explanation 2 to r.49 (1947 amendment) applies and attracts Art.311(2) fails as it was deleted by November 1949 amendment; new Explanation excludes probationary termination per terms/rules from amounting to removal/dismissal under r.49 or r.55

anchor.surface_text: But we find that r. 49 was further amended in November 1949 and by that amendment Explanation 2 was deleted and a new Explanation [...] The termination of employment- a of a person appointed on probation during or at the end of the period of probation, in accordance with the terms of the appointment [...] does not amount to removal or dismissal within the meaning of this rule or of rule 55.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1947 Explanation 2 deleted in 1949; substituted new Explanation in force in 1952 governs case; termination accords with terms and rules, not punishment

holdings.text: r.55-B applies to the appellant and is not excluded by r.3(a)

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3 a thus excludes the application of the Rules only in case of persons for whose appointment and conditions of employment special provision is made by or under any law [...] It cannot be said therefore that the term already mentioned [...] is a special provision by virtue of any law [...] We hold that r. 55-B will apply to the appellant and is not excluded by r. 3 a .

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.3(a) exception applies only to special provisions by or under law; standard probation term in appointment letter not such provision

holdings.text: The appellant was afforded the protection of r.55-B before termination

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the appellants contention must be rejected. The appellant was apprised of the grounds on which it was proposed to discharge him. [...] there is in our opinion sufficient compliance with r. 55-B. Generally speaking the purpose of a notice under r. 55-B is to ascertain [...] This is what was done in the present case and it cannot therefore be said that the appellant was not given the opportunity envisaged by r. 55-B.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dec 1951 letter apprised defects and gave opportunity to improve; July 1952 notice listed grounds for termination and opportunity to show cause; explanation considered and found unsatisfactory; constitutes compliance

holdings.text: r.55-B requires only that probationer be apprised of grounds (fault/unsuitability) for proposed termination and given opportunity to show cause/explanation; does not require elaborate r.55 procedure applicable to punitive removal/dismissal/reduction under Art.311(2)

anchor.surface_text: But what is urged is that the elaborate procedure provided in r. 55 should have been gone through under r. 55-B also. Rule 55 however deals with cases of removal, dismissal or reduction in rank [...] That procedure is not meant to be applicable under r. 55-B which deals with the discharge of a probationer which is not a punishment at all. Therefore in a case covered by r. 55-B all that is required is that the defects noticed [...]

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual distinction: r.55-B for non-punitive probationer discharge vs r.55 for major punishments under Art.311(2); purpose is to assess suitability after explanation

precedents.citation: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India 1

anchor.surface_text: see, Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India 1 . Further it is equally well settled that a government servant who is on probation can be discharged and such discharge would number amount to dismissal or removal within the meaning of Art. 311 2 and would number attract the protection of that Article where the services of a probationer are terminated in accordance with the rules and number by way of punishment. 1 1958 S. C. R, 828.

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: where the services of a temporary government servant are terminated not by way of punishment, Art. 311 will not apply and the services of such a servant can be terminated under the terms of the contract or by giving him the usual one months notice

precedents.citation: The State of Orissa v. Rant Narain Das 1

anchor.surface_text: A probationer has numberright to the post held by him and under the terms of his appointment he is liable to be discharged at any time during the period of his probation subject to the rules governing such cases see The State of Orissa v. Rant Narain Das 1 . The appellant in the present case was undoubtedly a probationer. There is also numberdoubt that the termination of his service was number by way of punishment and cannot therefore amount to dismissal or removal within the meaning of Art. 311. 1 1961 S.C.R. 606

precedents.case_name: State of Orissa v. Rant Narain Das
precedents.cited_proposition: a probationer has no right to the post held by him and under the terms of his appointment he is liable to be discharged at any time during the period of his probation subject to the rules governing such cases

anchor.surface_text: But we find that r. 49 was further amended in November 1949 and by that amendment Explanation 2 was deleted and a new Explanation [...] The termination of employment- a of a person appointed on probation during or at the end of the period of probation, in accordance with the terms of the appointment [...] does not amount to removal or dismissal within the meaning of this rule or of rule 55.
We therefore dismiss the appeal, though for slightly different reasons.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3 a thus excludes the application of the Rules only in case of persons for whose appointment and conditions of employment special provision is made by or under any law [...] It cannot be said therefore that the term already mentioned [...] is a special provision by virtue of any law [...] We hold that r. 55-B will apply to the appellant and is not excluded by r. 3 a .
We therefore dismiss the appeal, though for slightly different reasons.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the appellants contention must be rejected. The appellant was apprised of the grounds on which it was proposed to discharge him. [...] there is in our opinion sufficient compliance with r. 55-B. Generally speaking the purpose of a notice under r. 55-B is to ascertain [...] This is what was done in the present case and it cannot therefore be said that the appellant was not given the opportunity envisaged by r. 55-B.
We therefore dismiss the appeal, though for slightly different reasons.
